qas.question: Action was taken to boycott which company?
Who was the biggest shareholder of Carrefour?
Where were anti-protesters blocked from entering a Carrefour store with Chinese flags?
Who was said to have given money to the Dalai Lama?
What method did the Chinese government use to ease the boycott situation?
What French company was being boycotted?

context: China: In China, the torch was first welcomed by Politburo Standing Committee member Zhou Yongkang and State Councilor Liu Yandong. It was subsequently passed onto CPC General Secretary Hu Jintao. A call to boycott French hypermart <a0_0><a6_0>Carrefour<a6_0/><a0_0/> from May 1 began spreading through mobile text messaging and online chat rooms amongst the Chinese over the weekend from April 12, accusing the company's major shareholder, <a1_0><a4_0>the LVMH Group<a4_0/><a1_0/>, of donating funds to the Dalai Lama. There were also calls to extend the boycott to include French luxury goods and cosmetic products. According to the Washington Times on April 15, however, the Chinese government was attempting to "calm the situation" through <a5_0>censorship<a5_0/>: "All comments posted on popular Internet forum Sohu.com relating to a boycott of Carrefour have been deleted." Chinese protesters organized boycotts of the French-owned retail chain Carrefour in major Chinese cities including <a3_0>Kunming<a3_0/>, Hefei and Wuhan, accusing the French nation of pro-secessionist conspiracy and anti-Chinese racism. Some burned French flags, some added Nazism's Swastika to <a2_0>the French flag<a2_0/>, and spread short online messages calling for large protests in front of French consulates and embassy. The Carrefour boycott was met with anti-boycott demonstrators who insisted on entering one of the Carrefour stores in Kunming, only to be blocked by boycotters wielding large Chinese flags and hit by water bottles. The BBC reported that hundreds of people demonstrated in Beijing, Wuhan, Hefei, Kunming and Qingdao.
